answers.a: E106 is flavin mononucleotide (FMN), also called riboflavin-5′-phosphate—a vitamin B2 derivative used as a yellow food color and enzyme cofactor, typically made by fermentation or synthesis.

answers.q: what is system error e106 xbox one
answers.a: Unrelated to food additives; in food labeling, E106 refers to flavin mononucleotide (riboflavin-5′-phosphate), a vitamin B2-based colorant/cofactor.

answers.q: 5. explain the change in voltage when the flavin mononucleotide is added to the chloroplasts.
answers.a: FMN is a redox cofactor that can accept and donate electrons, so adding it can modify electron transport and the thylakoid proton gradient, transiently changing the membrane potential (voltage) across the membrane.

answers.q: e106 error xbox what does it mean
answers.a: That code is unrelated to foods; E106 on foods denotes flavin mononucleotide (riboflavin-5′-phosphate), a vitamin B2-derived yellow colorant/cofactor.
If this refers to a device error, it’s unrelated; in food contexts, E106 means flavin mononucleotide (riboflavin-5′-phosphate), a vitamin B2-based color additive and enzyme cofactor.
